title: Nancy Pelosi’s Husband Sold Visa Stock, Invested in Property
text:
Text size

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi recently disclosed financial transactions made by her husband, businessman and investor Paul Pelosi.

Paul Pelosi sold Visa stock (ticker: V) and invested in office buildings in August, according to a form Speaker Pelosi filed with the Clerk of the House of Representatives.

Paul Pelosi didn’t respond to a request for comment on his transactions. Speaker Pelosi’s office didn’t respond to a request for comment.

According to Speaker Pelosi’s filing, and an amended form, Paul Pelosi sold 2,000 shares of Visa on Aug. 7 for a total of $200,002 to $500,000. Specific values aren’t required for disclosure, only ranges. Visa stock traded between $170.34 and $175.73 on that day, and, assuming the sale was through the open market, the range of the total sale price can be narrowed to $340,680 to $351,460.

Editor's Choice

Speaker Pelosi’s 2018 disclosure form showed that Paul Pelosi owned Visa stock valued between $5 million and $25 million at the end of the year. He received $15,001 to $25,000 in dividends from his Visa stock in 2018.

Paul Pelosi also invested between $250,001 and $500,000 in REOF XXI, a limited-liability company that is acquiring “three unique office buildings with a common address of 222 Kearny Street in San Francisco,” according to Speaker Pelosi’s filing.

Inside Scoop is a regular Barron’s feature covering stock transactions by corporate executives and board members—so-called insiders—as well as large shareholders, politicians, and other prominent figures. Due to their insider status, these investors are required to disclose stock trades with the Securities and Exchange Commission or other regulatory groups.

Write to Ed Lin at edward.lin@barrons.com and follow @BarronsEdLin.
description: Investor Paul Pelosi sold 2,000 shares of Visa in August, and invested in a limited-liability company that is acquiring office buildings in San Francisco.
